Title: 2016 Dielectrophoresis Meeting at MIT

This project will provide travel funds to partially support approximately 30 graduate and post doctoral students and junior faculty to attend the 2016 Dielectrophoresis at MIT, in Cambridge, MA from July 13-15, 2016. This meeting is designed to provide an intimate setting for engineers and scientists with expertise in dielectrophoresis and non-linear electrokinetics can discuss research frontiers. Dielectrophoresis is a well-known particle manipulation technique that has been able to capture, sort, concentrate, and characterize a variety of particles and biological entities as small as a few nanometers. The recent, rapid expansion of DEP has demonstrated that this technique is a viable method for micro-total analytical systems, especially for biological and health care microsystems. The conference is organized into ten sessions. This meeting includes a plenary session with a diverse group of eminent researchers that represents the most exciting advances in non-linear electrokinetics and dielectrophoresis.

Funding from the National Science Foundation would be used for student and postdoc conference expenses and junior faculty, enabling more young US engineers and scientists to participate in Dielectrophoresis 2016. The expected outcomes include:
1. Enable greater participation by junior faculty and thus facilitating networking opportunities and establish international collaborations with veteran researchers.
2. Disseminate public knowledge on dielectrophoresis (and related topics) with students writing and posting session and conference summaries on dielectrophoresis.org and live-Tweet Dielectrophoresis 2016.
In addition to the development of human resources, the support provided will allow presentation of the latest research results from the most innovative academic laboratories around the country.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2016 Dielectrophoresis Meeting was held July 13-15, 2016 in Cambridge, MA on the campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.  This meeting involved participants from various sectors of the research community including academia, industry, and federal research laboratories.  The 2016 DEP Meeting was highly successful, building upon the momentum of the first DEP Meeting, which was held in July 2014 in London.  There were over 50 attendees at this meeting from 13 different countries including the United States, Mexico, India, France, Turkey, Spain, the United Kingdom, and Singapore. This meeting was designed to provide an intimate setting where those old and new to the area of dielectrophoresis and non-linear electrokinetics can discuss research frontiers.  Funding from the National Science Foundation was used for several purposes including, increased student participation in the meeting, travel support for early career faculty, and travel support for distinguished speakers from underrepresented groups.  Student participants in the meeting received additional training by taking an active leadership role in the administration of the conference by helping to convene a subset of the technical sessions. The participation of undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral research scientists is valuable training necessary to foster an internationally competitive workforce in the United States.  This is especially relevant in the fields of electrokinetics and microfluidics (of which dielectrophoresis is a subset), which are rapidly changing, and there is limited availability for relevant coursework. The meeting included several opportunities for informal interaction including a networking reception, conference banquet, and interactive poster sessions.
